awd_titl_txt: Driving Low-Income Mothers to Greater Success: The Impact of Ride-hailing on Employment and Income
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will use new research methods to investigate whether providing subsidized or free transportation to low-income mothers will increase their labor force participation and employment.  It does so by providing free or subsidized transportation to a selected group of low income mothers and comparing their labor market efforts and outcomes to low income mothers who do not receive transport subsidy.  The research will answer two specific questions: (i) will providing subsidized ride-hailing services to the poor enable better access to employment, training, and social services?  (ii) will subsidized transportation raise labor force participation and generate benefits that outweigh the costs?  Low-skilled workers in urban America are often concentrated in areas that are far from jobs that match their skills. The high cost of transportation poses special problems for low-income mothers with children, given their child care responsibilities making it difficult and costly for them to find jobs if they rely on public transportation.  New technology that makes ride-hailing, such as those provided by UBER and LYFT, possible offers flexible, convenient, and relatively inexpensive transportation that does not require private car ownership.  The results of this research will help increase labor market participation and employment of low-income mothers, thus improving the living standards of these mothers.

This project will empirically test the hypothesis that reducing transportation cost to low income mothers will increase their labor market participation and employment, using a large-scale randomized control trial (RCT).  Leveraging the emergence of ride-hailing as a new transportation option, the PIs will provide free rides to the treatment group of low-income mothers and compare employment and other outcomes to a demographically equivalent control group.   The PIs will work in partnership with UBER technologies and will exploit the diffusion of smartphones among the poor to track the impact of lower transportation costs on employment and wages.  GPS technology will also be extensively used to track the mobility of participants as they travel to search for, and go to work.  In addition to self-reported data collected from participants, the PIs will use data collected by local governments to supplement the research efforts.  The results of this research will help increase labor market participation and employment of low-income mothers, thus improving the living standards of these mothers

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past six decades, social scientists have extensively investigated the idea that inadequate transportation holds back the socioeconomic progress of low-income residents of American cities.  These transportation barriers are likely to be especially salient for low-income mothers, who balance work with childcare responsibilities.  However, there is a lack of experimental evidence showing that better transportation actually leads to better socioeconomic outcomes.  Many existing studies document a statistical relationship between inadequate transportation and poor socioeconomic outcomes, but both could be affected by unobserved individual characteristics.  For example, individuals seeking better job outcomes could deliberately relocate to places with better mass transit.  

Our project addressed this gap in the prior scientific literature by conducting a randomized controlled trial involving more than 1,000 low-income mothers in the Pittsburgh region.  Participants were randomly assigned to a treatment group that received up to $200 in free rides from a large ridehailing service each month for six months or to a control group that could take up to $200 in free rides for only one month.  All participants were required to download and use a smartphone app that used their phone’s GPS capabilities to track geographic mobility over the six-month active study period.  Participants were also compensated for filling out digital surveys that explored their employment, commuting, and job search activities.  Members of the treatment group were asked to use these surveys to explain how they used their free rides.  Collaboration with the Allegheny County Department of Human Services (ACDHS) allowed us to leverage the detailed data in the unemployment insurance (UI) system to track the employment and quarterly income of nearly all participants during the six-month active study period and beyond.

Statistical analysis of the GPS data collected by our smartphone app suggested large, positive, statistically significant effects of our treatment on the geographic mobility of participants.  Depending on the statistical approach and the measure of mobility used, these estimates ranged from 35% to 236%.  The overall distribution of estimates supports the conclusion that treatment roughly doubled the geographic mobility of the modal participant.  A comparison of the free rides taken to the travel times and routes required by public transit suggests that our treatment also significantly reduced the length and variance of travel times.  Survey responses indicate that participants used the free rides for job commutes and job searches, but they also used them to access medical care, interact with the court system, shop outside their neighborhoods, and access parks and other amenities.

Long lags between the collection of UI data and the transfer of these data to ACDHS have limited our ability to track the impact of our treatment on socioeconomic mobility, but our preliminary analyses point to a 13 percentage point increase in the likelihood of formal employment that is statistically significant and a nearly $800 increase in quarterly income, although this latter effect is not statistically significant at conventional levels.  These effects peak three quarters after initial enrollment and appear to persist even after access to free rides ends.  As we continue to obtain more data on participants’ income and employment during the six-month active study period and beyond, the statistical precision of our estimates may increase.  If our initial findings are strengthened by subsequent analyses, then we would be led conclude that subsidized access to ridehailing has large effects on socioeconomic mobility, at least for low-income mothers, and that the effects appear large enough to justify the cost of the subsidy.  

Our project also demonstrates the degree to which the diffusion of smartphones, even among low-income populations, and the ease with which apps leveraging the expanding capabilities of these smartphones can be developed and disseminated, opens up new opportunities for conducting field experiments in the economics of transportation and related areas.  Our project also shows how the combination of new data sets collected through smartphone apps with existing longitudinal administrative data sets measuring socioeconomic outcomes can create new research opportunities for economists and other quantitative social scientists.  We are already applying these new tools and approaches to other projects, and we expect that other quantitative social scientists will join us in taking advantage of these new opportunities.
